title: Acceleration Equation
text: One use for the derivative is to analyze motion along a line. Let s(t) be a function giving the position of an object at time $$t$$. The acceleration of the object at time $$t$$ is given by a(t) $$=$$ v'(t) $$=$$ s''(t), where a(t) is the acceleration, v'(t) is the derivative of the velocity, and s''(t) is the double derivative of s(t). First, solve for s'(t) or v(t).
speech: One use for the derivative is to analyze motion along a line. Let s(t) be a function giving the position of an object at time  t . First, solve for s'(t) or v(t).

title: Taking the First Derivative of s(t)
speech: s(t)  is equal to   2 t cubed,  -  15 t squared,  +  36 t  -  10 \ns'(t)  is equal to   3 times 2, t raised to the 3 minus 1 power  -  2 times 15, t raised to the 2 minus 1 power  +  36 \ns'(t)  is equal to   6 t squared,  -  30 t  +  36
pacedSpeech: 3 times 2, t raised to the 3 minus 1 power
-   2 times 15, t raised to the 2 minus 1 power

title: Second Derivative: s''(t)
text: Now that you have calculated s'(t), what is s''(t)?
speech: Now that you have calculated s'(t), what is s''(t)?
pacedSpeech: Now that you have calculated s'(t), what is s''(t)?

title: Taking the Second Derivative of s(t)
speech:
s'(t)  is equal to   6 t squared,  -  30 t  +  36 
s''(t)  is equal to   2 times 6, t raised to the 2 minus 1 power  -  30 
s''(t)  is equal to,   12 t  -  30 
Thus, a(t)  is equal to,   12 t  -  30
pacedSpeech: 2 times 6, t raised to the 2 minus 1 power
